cab.content: From Secretary of State to Viceroy, Foreign Department,20th June 1917.(Repeated to Sir P. Cox.)[P 2308] Foreign Secret. Your telegram of 13th June. River Conservancy inMesopotamia. What we want is to ensure that military requirements which" are for time being paramount are met with as little detriment as possible toirrigation present and potential. Garrow is said to be well. qualified asirrigation expert. He must be. now in Mesopotamia, and working underInland Water. Directorate. Would Cox.be satisfied with provisos suggestedby you or does he think it essential to have separate irrigation, expert onhis own staff wholly independent of military organisation, and withoutadministrative or executive powers ? War Office favour former alternative,and we do not wish to overload establishments unnecessarily.From Secretary of State to Viceroy, Foreign Department,20th June 1917.J(Repeated to Sir P. Cox.)Foreign Secret. My telegram of 23rd May. Officers for Mesopotamia.Clayton unwilling to accept, and in view of political objections to hisremoval from Egypt at present juncture His Majesty's Government do notpropose to press him further. Wingate is being urged to find substitutewith suitable qualifications. Failing that can Cox make any suggestion?Is Dobbs available, if health permits ?From Secretary of State to Viceroy, Army Department,20th June 1917.Your telegram of 19th May, No. 7358. South Persia Rifles Wholequestion has been carefully considered by His Majesty's Government in light^Markings telegrams, Nob. 202 and 203. It is proposed to await receipt ofSykes's provisional scheme of organisation before passing hnal orders.
